com.codemelon.graph

Class DiGraph

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.codemelon.graph.DiGraph
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Graph

    public class DiGraph
extends java.lang.Object
    Graph class supporting insertion and removal of both vertices and edges. Labeling for vertices is assumed to occur outside of this class. The advantage is that various checks on vertices can then occur much faster than they would if we had to run through the values in a hash. Before inserting or removing an edge, we need to check whether the graph contains its vertices. And when inserting a vertex, we need to check that it isn't already present. Both of these checks would be cumbersome if we implemented the graph as a map of a label to a vertex.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      DiGraph()
      Default constructor.
      DiGraph(java.util.Collection<Vertex> initialVertices)
      Initializes the Graph to contain the vertices in the collection and clears the adjacency set of all vertices in the collection.
      DiGraph(int initialCapacity)
      Constructor explicitly specifying the expected number of vertices the graph will contain.

    • Constructor Detail

      • DiGraph

        public DiGraph()
        Default constructor. Creates an empty graph with a default initial capacity of 16 vertices.

      • DiGraph

        public DiGraph(int initialCapacity)
        Constructor explicitly specifying the expected number of vertices the graph will contain. For large graphs in which the approximate number of vertices is known in advance, use of this constructor will result in significantly improved performance.
        Parameters:
        initialCapacity -

      • DiGraph

        public DiGraph(java.util.Collection<Vertex> initialVertices)
        Initializes the Graph to contain the vertices in the collection and clears the adjacency set of all vertices in the collection.
        Parameters:
        initialVertices - collection of vertices to include in the Graph

    • Method Detail

      • addVertex

        public boolean addVertex(Vertex v)
        Inserts v if it is not already present.
        Parameters:
        v - vertex to be inserted
        Returns:
        true if the graph did not already contained the specified vertex

      • removeVertex

        public boolean removeVertex(Vertex v)
        Remove a vertex from the graph. The vertex is removed along with its adjacency list, and it is also removed from the adjacency set of all other vertices in the graph. After this method call, not only will the vertex not belong to the graph, but the adjacency list of the vertex will be cleared.
        Parameters:
        v - vertex to be removed from the graph
        Returns:
        true if the vertex was found in the graph

      • addEdge

        public boolean addEdge(Vertex from,
              Vertex to)
        Inserts edge if not already present. Returns false if the edge was already present in the graph.
        Parameters:
        from - source vertex
        to - target vertex
        Returns:
        true if the edge was not previously present in the graph

      • removeEdge

        public boolean removeEdge(Vertex from,
                 Vertex to)
        Removes the specified edge if it is present. If the edge is not found, returns false and does nothing.
        Parameters:
        from - edge's source vertex
        to - edge's target vertex
        Returns:
        true if the edge was found

      • containsEdge

        public boolean containsEdge(Vertex from,
                   Vertex to)
        Shows whether or not the graph contains the specified edge
        Parameters:
        from - the tail or source vertex of the edge for which we are testing
        to - the head or target vertex of the edge for which we are testing
        Returns:
        true if the edge from the given tail to the given head exists in the graph.

        public void setEdgeColor(Vertex from,
                Vertex to,
                Color color)
        Set the color of an edge in the graph. Throws an exception if the edge doesn't belong to the graph
        Parameters:
        from - tail of the edge to be colored
        to - head of the edge to be colored
        color - color to assign to the edge.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the source vertex doesn't belong to the graph.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if there is no such edge in the graph (including the case where the target vertex doesn't belong to the graph)

      • setEdgeType

        public void setEdgeType(Vertex from,
               Vertex to,
               EdgeType edgeType)
        Set the edge type (TREE, BACK, FORWARD, CROSS) of an edge in the graph. Throws an exception if the edge doesn't belong to the graph.
        Parameters:
        from - tail of the edge whose type is to be set
        to - head of the edge whose type is to be set
        edgeType - type to assign to the edge (TREE, BACK, FORWARD, or CROSS)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the source vertex doesn't belong to the graph.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if there is no such edge in the graph (including the case where the target vertex doesn't belong to the graph)

      • setWeightEpsilon

        public void setWeightEpsilon(double weightEpsilon)
        Set the difference (epsilon) used to determine floating point equality for weight. This value initially defaults to 10-6. If the difference in 2 weights falls below this threshold, the weights are to be considered equal.

        Including this method allows us to use a custom value here if needed.

        Parameters:
        weightEpsilon - value to which to set the epsilon threshold for weight equality.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the given epsilon is not stricly positive (great than 0).

      • getWeightEpsilon

        public double getWeightEpsilon()
        Get the difference (epsilon) used to determine floating point equality for weight. This value initially defaults to 10-6. If the difference in 2 weights falls below this threshold, the weights are to be considered equal.
        Returns:
        epsilon value below which 2 weights are to be considered equal

      • areEqualWeights

        public boolean areEqualWeights(double w1,
                      double w2)
        Determines whether 2 weight values are to be considered equal in this graph.
        Parameters:
        w1 - first weight to compare
        w2 - second weight to compare
        Returns:
        true iff the absolute value of the difference between the 2 weights is less than the weightEpsilon for this graph
